original_title: Queens: Union Hall Street - Jamaica Avenue
text:
Union Hall Street, west side, north from the Long Island Railroad right of way, showing in a set of four views different aspects of the former Union Hall Academy. This institution first opened, May 1, 1792 in a Fulton Street (now Jamaica Avenue) structure and Malthy Gelston was the first principal. Dr. L.E.A. Eigenbrodt succeeded to this position which he held for 31 years until his death in 1828. During his incumbency this structure was erected; the cornerstone being laid in July 1820. Henry Onderdonck taught here during the years 1832 and 1865. 1873 saw the Academy close it's doors and the three buildings altered into dwellings which in 1876 were the homes of individuals named Smith, Hague, and Crane. A Childrens Court is stated to have been a lengthy occupant. They were still standing in 1929, tho a new apartment house was erected to the north of same.

Views 1 & 2: 1922.
3: May 1923.
4: April 1925.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection

original_title: Queens: Union Hall Street - Jamaica Avenue
text:
92-25 Union Hall Street, east side, between Jamaica Avenue and Archer Avenue, showing a Rupelyi homestead, which was erected in 1839.  Phebe Hagner was the owner in 1873. It was demolished in 1925 and a brick building erected upon its site.

View 1: June, 1924
Views 2,3: April 1, 1925

Eugene L. Armbruster

original_title: Queens: Union Hall Street - Jamaica Avenue
text:
Union Hall Street (extension of 162nd Street), west side, north from the Long Island Railroad right of way to Jamaica Ave., showing beyond the tracks, the former Union Hall Academy in a set of three views. Views Nos. 2 and 3 show the rear of the building as seen from 160th Street railroad bridge.

May 1923.
Views 1 and 2.
View 3: April 1929.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

original_title: Queens: Jamaica Avenue - Union Hall Street
text:
Jamaica Avenue, at the S. E. corner of Union Hall Street, showing an old frame dwelling in the heart of Jamaica business center. Union Hall Street can be seen running south toward Archer Avenue. This view is from the New York Title and Trust Co. building, across the B. M. T. elevated.

P. L. Sperr

April 1, 1932

original_title: Queens: Jamaica Avenue - Union Hall Street
text:
Jamaica Avenue, south side, between Union Hall and 160th Streets, showing (left to right) the Register's Office building, the Jamaica Savings Bank Building, the National Title and Guarantee Company Building (nine stories), and the Title Guarantee and Trust Company building. The views are westward across the elevated structure of the B.M.T. subway. In the center background of view 2 is the Jamaica Theatre building, on Archer Avenue and Twombly Place.

P. L. Sperr

April 1, 1932
Views 1,2

original_title: Queens: Jamaica Avenue - Union Hall Street
text:
Jamaica Avenue, south side, between Union Hall Street and New York Boulevard, showing several buildings in Jamaica's business district. The views are eastward across the "El" of the B.M.T. subway.

P. L. Sperr

April 1, 1932
Views 1,2
